Universal Spectral Correlations in the Chaotic Wave Function, and the Development of Quantum Chaos

Xiao Chen xchen@kitp.ucsb.edu Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics, University of California at Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA â€ƒâ€ƒ Andreas W.W. Ludwig Department of Physics, University of California at Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA
Abstract

We investigate the appearance of quantum chaos in a single many-body wave function by analyzing the statistical properties of the eigenvalues of its reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of a spatial subsystem Ağ´A. We find that (i): the spectrum of the density matrix is described by so-called Wishart random matrix theory, which (ii): exhibits besides level repulsion, spectral rigidity and universal spectral correlations between eigenvalues separated by distances ranging from one up to many mean level spacings, which we investigate. We use these universal spectral characteristics of the reduced density matrix as a definition of chaos in the wave function. A simple and precise characterization of such universal correlations in a spectrum is a segment of strictly linear growth at sufficiently long times, recently called the â€œrampâ€, of the spectral form factor which is the Fourier transform of the correlation function between a pair of eigenvalues. It turns out that Wishart and standard random matrix theory have the same universal â€œrampâ€. Specifically, here numerical results for the spectral form factor of the density matrix of generic non-integrable many-body systems, such as one-dimensional quantum Ising and Floquet spin models, are found to exhibit an universal â€œrampâ€ identical to that appearing for a â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (â€œPage stateâ€, or â€œHaar stateâ€). The density matrix of the latter is precisely the Wishart random matrix, the reduced density matrix of a completely random wave function. In addition, we study the development of chaos in the wave function by letting an initial direct product state evolve under the unitary time evolution. We find that the universal spectral correlations as manifested by the â€œrampâ€ set in as soon as the entanglement entropy begins to grow, and first develop for the eigenvalues at the top of the spectrum of the density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, subsequently spreading over the entire spectrum at later times. Finally, we study a prethermalized regime described by a generalized Gibbs ensemble, which develops in a rapidly driven Floquet model at intermediate times. We find that the prethermalized regime exhibits no chaos, as evidenced by the absence of a â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor of the density matrix, while the universal spectral correlations start to develop when the prethermalized regime finally relaxes at late times to the fully thermalized (infinite temperature) chaotic regime.

I Introduction

The characterization of chaos in quantum mechanical systems has a long history, and chaos plays a key role in the process of thermalization, i.e. relaxation to equilibrium in generic isolated many-body quantum systemsSrednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991). (See e.g. Ref.s Haake, 2013, Stoeckmann, 1999, T.Â Guhr, 1998, Dâ€™AlessioÂ andÂ Rigol, 2014 for a review.) It also plays an important role for the quantum nature of black holes.ShenkerÂ andÂ Stanford (2014a, b, 2015); MaldacenaÂ etÂ al. (2016); Kitaev (2014); CotlerÂ etÂ al. (2016) An important milestone in the study of quantum chaos has been the so-called Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjectureO.Â Bohigas (1984), which states that chaos manifests itself in the spectral properties of the Hamiltonian of a quantum system by exhibiting universal features which are the same as those of the spectrum of a random Hamiltonian matrix in the same symmetry class. Such universal features include, besides level repulsion statistics between adjacent spectral levels, spectral rigidity and more generally the correlation function between two levels which is universal for levels separated by energy scales that range from the mean level spacing to energy differences which can be much larger, up to scales at which model-dependent (â€œultravioletâ€) features set in. The corresponding universality classes are solely determined by the action of the anti-unitary time-reversal operator, giving rise to the three possible symmetry classes of spectral statistics depending on whether time reversal symmetry is absent (â€œGUEâ€, Dyson index Î²=2ğ›½2\beta=2), or is present and squares to the identiy operator (â€œGOEâ€, Dyson index Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1) or squares to minus the identity operator (â€œGSEâ€, Dyson index Î²=4ğ›½4\beta=4).

Spectral characteristics of a discrete spectrum of levels Eisubscriptğ¸ğ‘–E_{i} are conveniently described by the so-called spectral form factor 111See e.g. Ref.s T.Â Guhr, 1998, CotlerÂ etÂ al., 2016, which is the Fourier transform of the correlation function between two levels, and can be written in the form

It was shownBerry (1985); HannayÂ andÂ Ozorio De Almeida (1984) many years ago that in chaotic quantum systems with a small number of degrees of freedom whose classical limit is ergodic, the â€œrampâ€ for the energy spectrum of the Hamiltonian can be computed analytically in the semiclassical limit by making use of Gutzwillerâ€™s Trace FormulaGutzwiller (1990) and known properties of asymptotically long classical periodic orbits. In these cases, the time-scale Ï„0subscriptğœ0\tau_{0} characterizes the onset of potential non-universal contributions to gcâ€‹(Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœg_{c}(\tau) for Ï„â‰²Ï„0less-than-or-similar-toğœsubscriptğœ0\tau\lesssim\tau_{0} arising from short orbits. On the other hand, the spectral form factor has very recently formed a topic of extensive discussion in the context of the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model SachdevÂ andÂ Ye (1993); Kitaev (2015); MaldacenaÂ andÂ Stanford (2016), a strongly chaotic quantum system, whose Hamiltonian has been shown numerically to exhibit a spectrum possessing the expected â€œrampâ€. A recent lucid discussion of many aspects of the spectral form factor, with an emphasis on the Hamiltonian spectrum of the SYK model, can be found in Ref.Â CotlerÂ etÂ al., 2016. - In contrast, these universal spectral correlations are absent in an integrable system, where the spectral form factor exhibits no â€œrampâ€ (and the probability distribution for the spacing between adjacent levels is Poissonian).

In the present paper, we are going to show that the universal spectral correlations manifested by a strictly linear â€œrampâ€ already appear at the level of a single many-body wavefunction of a generic chaotic quantum system, without focusing attention on the spectrum of the Hamiltonian of the system; we also discuss periodically driven Floquet systems.

For thermalizing (chaotic) systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian (i.e. not Floquet systems), our work can be motivated by the connection between a typical state and the thermal ensemble, a notion inherent in the eigenstate thermalization hypothesisSrednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) (ETH), which we now briefly summarize as follows: Let |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle be a state at finite energy density e=E/Vğ‘’ğ¸ğ‘‰e=E/V (i.e. âŸ¨Ïˆ|H^|ÏˆâŸ©=quantum-operator-productğœ“^ğ»ğœ“absent\langle\psi|{\hat{H}}|\psi\rangle= E=ğ¸absentE= eâ€‹Vğ‘’ğ‘‰e\ V, where Vğ‘‰V is the volume), which can either be a highly excited exact eigenstate of a chaotic Hamiltonian H^^ğ»{\hat{H}} in the spatial volume Vğ‘‰V, or just a typical short-range entangled initial state (which is not an eigenstate of H^^ğ»{\hat{H}}) acted on by the corresponding unitary quantum mechanical time-evolution operator for a sufficiently long time. ETH states that the expectation value of a product of local operators in the state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle equals the thermal expectation value of this product at a temperature determined by eğ‘’e in the usual sense of microcanonical Statistical Mechanics. For Floquet systems, these expectations values in the analogous state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle are at infinite temperature.

Here we consider the reduced density matrix in a spatial subregion Ağ´A (BğµB =AÂ¯absentÂ¯ğ´={\bar{A}} is the complement of Ağ´A) of such a typical state,

Ï^A=TrBâ€‹|ÏˆâŸ©â€‹âŸ¨Ïˆ|.subscript^ğœŒğ´subscriptTrğµketğœ“brağœ“\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}=\mbox{Tr}_{B}\ |\psi\rangle\langle\psi|. (2)

We will show that the spectral form factor for the spectrum of eigenvalues Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A},

gâ€‹(Ï„)â‰¡âŸ¨âˆ‘i,jeâˆ’iâ€‹Ï„â€‹(Î»iâˆ’Î»j)âŸ©,ğ‘”ğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğœsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘—\displaystyle g(\tau)\equiv\langle\sum_{i,j}e^{-i\tau(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{j})}\rangle, (3)

exhibits a â€œrampâ€. As mentioned above, the presence of a â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor demonstrates the presence of universal spectral correlations over a possibly large range of scales (determined by Ï„0subscriptğœ0\tau_{0} and Ï„Hsubscriptğœğ»\tau_{H}) in the spectrum of eigenvalues of the density matrix. Thus, in this paper we use the presence of these universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix of a typical quantum state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle, as manifested by the presence of a â€œrampâ€ in the associated spectral form factor, to define the notion of quantum chaos in the state (i.e. â€œin the wavefunctionâ€). In particular, we will show at the technical level that spectral properties of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} are described by so-called Wishart random matrix theoryForrester (2010). As it turns out, Wishart random matrix theory exhibits universal spectral correlations idential to those appearing in standard (here555since we consider systems without time-reversal symmetry GUE) random matrix theory; in particular they have the same universal linear â€œrampâ€ (see Sect. IV.3 and Appendix B).

For systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian, we can look at this also from a slightly different angle: Instead of investigating the spectral statistics of the reduced density matrix, one may also be inclined to consider the spectral statistics of the associated entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^ğ»ğ¸{\hat{H}}_{E} defined by

Ï^A=ğ’©Eâˆ’1â€‹expâ¡{âˆ’Î²eâ€‹fâ€‹fâ€‹H^E}.subscript^ğœŒğ´superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ¸1subscriptğ›½ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“subscript^ğ»ğ¸\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}={\cal N}_{E}^{-1}\exp\{-\beta_{eff}{\hat{H}}_{E}\}. (4)

The spectral form factor for the entanglement Hamiltonian is obtained from (3) by letting Î»iâ†’â†’subscriptğœ†ğ‘–absent\lambda_{i}\to âˆ’lnâ¡Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–-\ln\lambda_{i}. As discussed in Appendix A, the two spectral form factors, of Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}_{A}} and of H^Esubscript^ğ»ğ¸{\hat{H}}_{E}, exhibit identical universal features in their respective level statistics. In particular, in a chaotic system they both exhibit a linear â€œrampâ€. Now, one may think of the entanglement Hamiltonian and of (4) in the light of a strong version of ETH proposed in Ref.Â GarrisonÂ andÂ Grover, 2015, which states that the reduced density matrix of the single state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle takes on a thermal form, Ï^A=subscript^ğœŒğ´absent{\hat{\rho}}_{A}= ğ’©Aâˆ’1â€‹expâ¡{âˆ’Î²â€‹H^A}superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ´1ğ›½subscript^ğ»ğ´{\cal N}_{A}^{-1}\exp\{-\beta{\hat{H}}_{A}\}, where H^Asubscript^ğ»ğ´{\hat{H}}_{A} is the physical (chaotic) Hamiltonian of the system, projected onto the region of subsystem Ağ´A. Note that this strong version of ETHGarrisonÂ andÂ Grover (2015) is a quite non-trivial statement because even though Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} is constructed from a single state [see (2)], this statement implies that Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} contains the knowledge of the entire Hamiltonian of the system, or rather at least of its projection onto Ağ´A. - Then, if one assumes the validity of the above-mentioned strong version of ETH, one would naturally expect that the universal correlations in the spectrum of the entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^ğ»ğ¸{\hat{H}}_{E} are directly inherited from those of the physical Hamiltonian H^Asubscript^ğ»ğ´{\hat{H}}_{A} (which, according to the Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjecture, is expected to exhibit universal spectral correlations). Thus, since we observe (as mentioned) that Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} and H^Esubscript^ğ»ğ¸{\hat{H}}_{E} exhibit the same universal features in their spectral form factors, it would be natural to expect the appearance the universal spectral correlations (and the â€œrampâ€) in the entanglement Hamiltonian of a single state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle. Put another way, for thermalizing (chaotic) systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian, our results can thus also be viewed as a confirmation of the strong version of ETH proposed in Ref. GarrisonÂ andÂ Grover, 2015.

In order to investigate explicitly the presence of the mentioned universal correlations in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix (2) in many-body quantum chaos, we numerically compute the spectral form factor of the density matrix of a typical single many-body wave function |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle [as defined in the paragraph above (2)], in two generic non-integrable one-dimensional systems: a Floquet spin model, and a quantum Ising model in both transverse and logitudinal field. As will be shown below in the bulk of the paper, we clearly observe for both systems a linear â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factors of their density matrices, confirming the corresponding universal spectral correlations in their spectra of eigenvalues. Furthermore, in order to provide a generic, model-independent description of the universal features of quantum chaos in a wave function, we consider a so-called â€œrandom pure stateâ€, or â€œPage stateâ€ (â€œHaar stateâ€)Page (1993),

|Î¨â€‹({Î±i})âŸ©=âˆ‘iÎ±iâ€‹|CiâŸ©,ketÎ¨subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ketsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–\displaystyle|\Psi(\{\alpha_{i}\})\rangle=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\ |C_{i}\rangle, (5)

in which the coefficients Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i} of the state in a fixed basis {|CiâŸ©}isubscriptketsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘–\{|C_{i}\rangle\}_{i} are random complex numbers subject solely to the normalization constraint, with a probability distribution invariant under unitary basis changes. The set of coefficients {Î±i}isubscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘–\{\alpha_{i}\}_{i} can thus be considered a row (or column) vector of a unitary random matrix (distributed according to the Haar measure). When we now form the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (5) in a spatial region Ağ´A, we obtain a random matrix which turns out to belong to the well-studied â€œWishart random matrix ensembleâ€ (see Sect. IV.1 below for a more detailed discussion). The probability distribution for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix and hence of the density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ are known analytically (as reviewed in Sect. IV.2), and the spectral form factor for Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} can be shown analytically (see Subsection IV.3 and Appendix B) to exhibit a linear â€œrampâ€ in the limit of large density matrices, reflecting the presence of universal spectral correlations in their spectra. As already mentioned, the linear â€œrampâ€ in gcâ€‹(Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœg_{c}(\tau) for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix turns out to be identical to that of standard random matrix theory in the same symmetry class (see Sect. IV.3 and Appendix B). The spectral form factor for the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ is discussed in detail in Sect. II.2 below. In Sect. II.3 we compare the numerically obtained spectral form factors of the Floquet and the quantum Ising systems with that of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (for the same system sizes) and find full agreement of the universal features. This means that Wishart random matrix theory describes the spectral correlations of the reduced density matrix of a single many-body wave function in typical chaotic systems of Hamiltonian and Floquet type in their universal regime, just as ordinary random matrix theory is thought to describe the level statistics of a chaotic Hamiltonian (according to the Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjectureO.Â Bohigas (1984).) The Floquet and quantum Ising systems considered in this paper lack time-reversal symmetry and so the â€œGUEâ€ Wishart random matrix ensemble will be appropriate.

Subsequently, we explore the important question of development of quantum chaos under quantum mechanical unitary time evolution. Recently, it has been proposed that the â€œout-of-time-orderedâ€ correlation function (OTOC) can probe the development of chaotic dynamics and scrambling of quantum information.LarkinÂ andÂ Ovchinnikov (1969); ShenkerÂ andÂ Stanford (2014a, b, 2015); MaldacenaÂ etÂ al. (2016); Kitaev (2014) At early times, the OTOC can exhibit an exponentially growing regime, the growth rate of which represents a quantum analog of the (classical) Lyapunov exponent. In this paper, we will study instead as an indicator of the development of quantum chaos the emergence of universal spectral correlations and of the corresponding â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor, in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) as a function of time tğ‘¡t in a quantum quench problem. ETH states that an (sufficiently general short-range entangled) initial state which is not an eigenstate, relaxes under the quantum mechanical time evolution, after a sufficiently long time, to a state which appears to be (in the sense of ETH, as reviewed above) in thermal equilibrium (at infinite temperature for Floquet systems).Srednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) Therefore, if we start with an initial direct product state, one expects that while the spectrum of the reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) will initially exhibit no spectral correlations, under the unitary time evolution a â€œrampâ€ will emerge after a sufficiently long time tğ‘¡t in its spectral form factor. We consider both (one-dimensional) Floquet and quantum Ising models and find that a â€œrampâ€ starts to develop as soon as the entanglement entropy begins to grow. More precisely, it is interesting to note that universal spectral correlations are first seen to appear for the eigenvalues at the top of the spectrum of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t), and subsequently spread out over the entire spectrum at later times.

We emphasize that there is no direct connection between the appearance of a volume law in the entanglement entropy and quantum chaos. In integrable systems, initial direct product states (as above) are typically expected to thermalize to a generalized Gibbs ensemble (GGE) after sufficiently long unitary time evolutionRigolÂ etÂ al. (2007, 2006); CalabreseÂ andÂ Cardy (2007); Cardy (2015). Although the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} for these GGE states possesses an entanglement entropy exhibiting a volume law, the eigenvalues of this density matrix are not expected to exhibit the discussed universal spectral correlations, in contrast to the reduced density matrix of chaotic (thermalizing) systems discussed above. To illustrate this point explicitly, we have constructed a rapidly driven Floquet system whose time evolution, starting out from a direct product state, exhibits a long, stable so-called prethermalized regimeMoriÂ etÂ al. (2016); AbaninÂ etÂ al. (2015, 2017); ElseÂ etÂ al. (2017) at intermediate times. This prethermalized regime, accompanied by a long plateau in the time-dependence of the entanglement entropy exhibiting a volume law, will be seen to be clearly devoid of chaos as evidenced from the absence of the characterisic universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of the density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t), which is manifested by the absence of a â€œrampâ€ in the corresponding spectral form factor. A linear â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor is seen to develop only when the prethermalized regime eventually relaxes at very late times to the fully thermalized chaotic regime, in which the conservation laws (approximately) present in the prethermalized regime cease to exist.

We end the introduction by mentioning some related work. Level repulsion statistics between adjacent levels of the density matrix of thermalizing systems with a main focus on disordered systems has been discussed in the context of work investigating Many-Body-Localization (MBL) in Ref.Â YangÂ etÂ al., 2017 and GeraedtsÂ etÂ al., 2016. Our work, in contrast, discusses spectral rigidity and, in particular, the universal spectral correlations and the â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor, focusing on non-random chaotic systems, and it elucidates the origins of these spectral correlations in the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state) and in Wishart random matrix theory, both for Hamiltonian and Floquet systems. Furthermore, we identify the development of chaos as the process of buildup of these spectral correlations in the density matrix under the unitary time-evolution. We also discuss a prethermal regime, lacking chaos, and its late-time relaxation to a chaotic state.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Sect. II, we first discuss the spectral form factor in the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state) and its linear â€œrampâ€. Then, we discuss the spectral form factors of typical wavefunctions of non-integrable Floquet and quantum Ising models for the same system sizes, and show that they both exhibit the same universal linear â€œrampâ€ as the â€œrandom pure stateâ€. In Sect. III, we discuss the development of chaos in these Floquet and Ising model wavefunctions by computing the time evolution of the spectral form factor. Moreover, we explore the development of chaos in a Floquet model which exhibits a long prethermal regime at intermediate times. In Sect. IV, we compute the spectral form factor in â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state) analytically by using some basic knowledge of the Wishart ensemble and compare the result with the numerical calculations in Sect. II. We summarize and conclude in Sect. V.

II Spectral Form Factor

II.1 General Discussion

We decompose the Hilbert space of the total system of dimension Nğ‘N (of which the â€œtypicalâ€ state |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle is an element) into a tensor product of the Hilbert spaces of the two subsystems, system Ağ´A with Hilbert space dimension NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A}, and system BğµB with Hilbert space dimension NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B} (i.e. N=NAâ€‹NBğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµN=N_{A}N_{B}). The spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau) for the NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A} eigenvalues Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} defined in (3) above, can be conveniently expressed666In the present paper we often follow the notations used in Ref. CotlerÂ etÂ al., 2016. in terms of the Fourier transform of the eigenvalue density

In the context of the spectrum of a random (GUE, GOE or GSE) Hamiltonian matrix, the connected spectral form factor gcâ€‹(Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœg_{c}(\tau) has been extensively discussed in the literature over many years.777See e.g. Ref. As already mentioned in the Introduction (Sect. I), the purpose of the average âŸ¨â€¦âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©â€¦\langle...\rangle in (7) and (8) is to remove non-universal rapid temporal fluctuationsPrange (1997) from the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau). In our work reported below, there will be a natural ensemble available over which to perform the average as an ensemble average: For the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state) discussed in Sect. Another way to remove the high-frequency fluctuations from the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau) is to coarse grain the latter in time Ï„ğœ\tau by convolution with a temporal â€œsmearing functionâ€ which eliminates high frequencies components from the signal. (For example, see Refs.Â CotlerÂ etÂ al., 2016; BalasubramanianÂ etÂ al., 2017.) Since the ensemble averages were more convenient for us, we did not use the coarse graining approach in the present work to remove the high frequency fluctuations.

II.2 Random pure state

Since, as already mentioned in the Introduction, this will turn out to provide a model-independent description of the universal properties of quantum chaos in a wave function, we first study the spectral form factor of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state), discussed in (5) and the paragraph below that equation. The reduced density matrix for a â€œrandom pure stateâ€ is also a random matrix and it turns out to belong to the so-called (unitary) Wishart ensemble with Dyson index Î²=2ğ›½2\beta=2, in which the spectral density satisfies the so-called Marchenko-Pastur distribution.Forrester (2010) (See Sect. IV for a review.)

Using this property, Page showedPage (1993) that the ensemble-averaged (von Neumann) entanglement entropy [EE] of the reduced density matrix for subsystem A of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ is equal to

âŸ¨SAâŸ©=logâ¡NAâˆ’NA2â€‹NB.delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ‘†ğ´subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğ´2subscriptğ‘ğµ\displaystyle\langle S_{A}\rangle=\log N_{A}-\frac{N_{A}}{2N_{B}}. (9)

(Recall that NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A} and NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B} are Hilbert space dimensions for subsystem A and its complement B, respectively, and we have assumed NAâ‰¤NBsubscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµN_{A}\leq N_{B} without loss of generality.)

Since the Hilbert space dimension NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A} grows exponentionally with the volume of subsystem Ağ´A, the entanglement entropy of the random product state exhibits according to (9) a volume law (as expected). For example, for the Ising-type systems considered in the present paper which have a local (onsite) Hilbert space dimension of two, we have NA=2LAsubscriptğ‘ğ´superscript2subscriptğ¿ğ´N_{A}=2^{L_{A}} where LAsubscriptğ¿ğ´L_{A} is the number of lattice sites of subsystem Ağ´A. We thus seen from (9) that the entanglement entropy of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ exhibits a volume law of maximal possible value (given the dimension of the onsite Hilbert space), up to a small subleading term which depends on the ratio of the Hilbert space dimensions of subsystems Ağ´A and BğµB, which we denote by Î±â‰¡NA/NBğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµ\alpha\equiv N_{A}/N_{B}. The latter subleading term in (9) takes on its maximal value 1/2121/2 at Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1, and approaches zero as NAâ‰ªNBmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµN_{A}\ll N_{B}.

It it known analytically (as reviewed in Sect. IV below) that the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix exhibit the same universal spectral correlations as those of the Hamiltonian of the GUE random matrix ensemble, which manifest themselves, as already mentioned, in the connected spectral form factor gcâ€‹(Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœg_{c}(\tau). We have computed numerically the (non-connected) spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)=âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix, describing the reduced density matrix of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€. The results are plotted in Fig.Â 2 which shows that when Î±=NA/NB<1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµ1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}<1, there is an intermediate linear â€œrampâ€ where gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle grows linearly with time Ï„ğœ\tau. The presence of the â€œrampâ€ demonstrates the presence of the mentioned universal spectral correlations, as discussed analytically in Sect.Â IV below (compare also Fig. 1).

Continuing with Î±=NA/NB<1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµ1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}<1, we also observe in Fig.Â 2 an early time regime where gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle drops down quickly to a minimum value. The three time-regimes mentioned in Sect. We finally discuss a subtlety occuring when Î±=NA/NB=1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµ1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}=1. The length of the â€œrampâ€ in gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau) increases with the number of eigenvalues that exhibit universal spectral correlations.CotlerÂ etÂ al. (2016) We clearly see from Fig.Â 2 that both the length of â€œrampâ€, and the position of Ï„psubscriptğœğ‘\tau_{p}, are linearly proportional (on a log scale) to logâ¡NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´\log N_{A}.

We finally want to mention that the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} studied in this section belongs to the Wishart random matrix ensemble lacking time-reversal symmetry, described by Dyson index Î²=2ğ›½2\beta=2 (i.e. the â€œGUE-typeâ€ version of the Wishart random matrix ensemble). We can also consider a density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} described by a Wishart ensemble with Dyson index Î²=1,4ğ›½14\beta=1,4 (the â€œGOEâ€ and the â€œGSEâ€ version of the Wishart random matrix ensemble), in which the details of the universal spectral correlations are slightly different. In the spectral form factor, these modified spectral correlations between the eigenvalues are reflected in a similar but slightly more complicated universal â€œrampâ€.Forrester (2010) While a straightforward extension, we will not discuss details of these cases explicitly in this paper.

II.3 Floquet and Quantum Ising models

For a generic chaotic system with a time-independent Hamiltonian H^^ğ»{\hat{H}}, we expect that for the states |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle with energy expectation value Eğ¸E (=âŸ¨Ïˆ|H^|ÏˆâŸ©=eâ€‹Vabsentquantum-operator-productğœ“^ğ»ğœ“ğ‘’ğ‘‰=\langle\psi|{\hat{H}}|\psi\rangle=eV, where eğ‘’e is the energy density) in the middle of the spectrum of H^^ğ»{\hat{H}}, the resulting density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the subsystem is well thermalized and its entanglement entropy exhibits a volume law. As already mentioned in the introduction, one might expect based on notions from ETH that the spectrum of this reduced density matrix exhibits universal spectral correlations. In this section, we will show more specifically for both, one-dimensional Floquet and quantum Ising models, that the spectra of the reduced density matrices of the above-mentioned states |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle have the same universal properties as those of the â€œrandom pure statesâ€ (Page states), and that the universal features of their reduced density matrix are in fact those of the Wishart random matrix, which is the reduced density matrix of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€, the density matrix of a completely random wave function.

For practical reasons, instead of diagonalizing the Hamiltonian (or the Floquet operator) to investigate the spectral statistics the reduced density matix obtained for the subsystem for a typical eigenstatefoo , we will choose a set of initial product states |Î¨0âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨0|\Psi_{0}\rangle (which thus are not entangled) and let them evolve under the unitary evolution governed by the Floquet operator or Ising Hamiltonian, i.e.,

|Î¨0â€‹(t)âŸ©=Uâ€‹(t)â€‹|Î¨0âŸ©.ketsubscriptÎ¨0ğ‘¡ğ‘ˆğ‘¡ketsubscriptÎ¨0\displaystyle|\Psi_{0}(t)\rangle=U(t)|\Psi_{0}\rangle. (10)

This is actually a quantum quench problem. For a generic non-integrable system, the initial wave function |Î¨0âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨0|\Psi_{0}\rangle will eventually, at long times tğ‘¡t, thermalize under its own dynamics and the reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t)=TrBâ€‹|Î¨0â€‹(t)âŸ©â€‹âŸ¨Î¨0â€‹(t)|subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡subscriptTrğµketsubscriptÎ¨0ğ‘¡brasubscriptÎ¨0ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t)=\mbox{Tr}_{B}|\Psi_{0}(t)\rangle\langle\Psi_{0}(t)| will approach the reduced density matrix of a generic eigenstate of the Hamiltonian.Srednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) Universal spectral correlations will develop in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix starting from such unentangled initial states, so that the final state obtained after sufficiently long time evolution will be fully thermalized. The advantage of this method is that we can work with relatively large systems (the time evolution operator simply has to be applied for a long time). Specifically, we will consider below one-dimensional Floquet and Ising models with L=20ğ¿20L=20 lattice sites.

II.3.1 Floquet model

We first consider a Floquet model. It is known that Floquet systems can thermalize very rapidly due to the absence of any conservation laws.KimÂ etÂ al. (2014); Dâ€™AlessioÂ andÂ Rigol (2014); LazaridesÂ etÂ al. (2014); PonteÂ etÂ al. (2015); ZhangÂ etÂ al. (2015) The properties of such periodically driven systems are determined by the unitary time evolution operator over one period, i.e., the Floquet operator. Following Ref.Â KimÂ etÂ al., 2014, we consider the following Floquet operator

We choose a set of initial states which are random product states (hence unentangled, having vanishing EE) with the direction of the spin at each lattice site chosen independently from a uniform distribution on the Bloch sphere.

III The development of chaos and thermalization in Floquet and Ising model

In this section, we study the development of quantum chaos in the many-body wave function. Starting (as before) with an initial product state |Î¨0âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨0|\Psi_{0}\rangle, the time-evolved reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) of the subsystem,

Ï^Aâ€‹(t)=TrBâ€‹[U^â€‹(t)â€‹|Î¨0âŸ©â€‹âŸ¨Î¨0|â€‹U^â€ â€‹(t)],subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡subscriptTrğµdelimited-[]^ğ‘ˆğ‘¡ketsubscriptÎ¨0brasubscriptÎ¨0superscript^ğ‘ˆâ€ ğ‘¡\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t)=\mbox{Tr}_{B}\left[{\hat{U}}(t)|\Psi_{0}\rangle\langle\Psi_{0}|{\hat{U}}^{{\dagger}}(t)\right], (15)

will eventually thermalize under the unitary time evolution operator U^â€‹(t)^ğ‘ˆğ‘¡{\hat{U}}(t) of a generic non-integrable system, and its spectrum will in the process develop universal spectral correlations, manifested by a linear â€œrampâ€ in the corresponding spectral form factor. In this section we ask: At what times tğ‘¡t, under the quantum mechanical time evolution, does the â€œrampâ€ emerge, and how does it evolve in time tğ‘¡t until it reaches its final fully thermalized regime at long times? That is, we will be studying the development of chaos in the density matrix. To answer these questions, we will study the spectral form factor at different times tğ‘¡t before Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) has fully thermalized.

III.1 Floquet System

We first study the Floquet system defined in (11) and (12).KimÂ etÂ al. (2014); Dâ€™AlessioÂ andÂ Rigol (2014); LazaridesÂ etÂ al. (2014); PonteÂ etÂ al. (2015); ZhangÂ etÂ al. As is clearly seen from the inset of Fig.Â 5, at time-step n=30ğ‘›30n=30 the deviation of the EE from its Page value is negligible.

We note that we have obtained the above results upon computing the spectral form factor by using in (3) or (7) all the eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t=nâ€‹T)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘‡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT). Actually, in order to gain additional insight, it is useful to limit the eigenvalues used to compute the spectral form factor in (3) or (7) to a subset lying in a window around a fixed eigenvalue, and to compute the spectral form factor by only using the eigenvalues of the density matrix in this window. This procedure can then detect â€œlocal universal spectral correlationsâ€ characterizing the correlations amongst the eigenvalues in this window. In Fig.Â 6, we present results for the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle for a window of 10 consecutive eigenvalues at the top of spectrum999 We choose here the 10 largest eigenvalues, of a total of approx. NA=500subscriptğ‘ğ´500N_{A}=500 levels of Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. in Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. We notice the appearance of a linear â€œrampâ€ as early as at time-step n=5ğ‘›5n=5. As we move the window of eigenvalues away from the top to the bottom of the spectrum of the density matrix101010We choose here the 10 smallest eigenvalues, of a total of approx. NA=500subscriptğ‘ğ´500N_{A}=500 levels of Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. , we find that the linear â€œrampâ€ develops only at later time-steps - here at n=11ğ‘›11n=11 (Fig.Â 6). This result demonstrates that in the Floquet model, as time tğ‘¡t evolves, the universal spectral correlations first emerge at the top of spectrum of Ï^Aâ€‹(t=nâ€‹T)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘‡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT) and subsequently spread over the entire spectrum at later times tğ‘¡t. This behavior, i.e. the fact that not the entire spectrum of the density matrix develops the spectral correlations uniformly in time tğ‘¡t, is also responsible for the shallowness of the dip that appears, when the time-step nğ‘›n is between 11 and 15, in the plot in Fig.Â 5 of the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle which uses the entire spectrum as input.

Finally, we would like to discuss the connection between the linear growth of the EE and the development of universal spectral correlations. When we look at the magnitudes of the eigenvalues of ÏAâ€‹(t)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ‘¡\rho_{A}(t) at early times, we find that there are only a few of them which are appreciably different from zero; and it is them that exhibit the spectral correlations and are also responsible for the observed value of the EE. Actually, they also give rise to the volume law in the EE for smaller subsystem sizes. As time evolves, more and more eigenvalues become appreciably different from zero. They develop spectral correlations and lead to the linear growth of the EE. This is in contrast with an integrable system, where the linear growth of the EE is due to the ballistic propagation of quasiparticlesCalabreseÂ andÂ Cardy (2007) and there are no spectral correlations between the eigenvalues and hence there is no â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor.111111See the last paragraph before Sec. III.3 and Fig. 9. In Sec. III.3 we will show an example of such a phenomenon within a Floquet system.

III.2 Ising Model

In this section we investigate the development of chaos in a quantum Ising model, where the thermalization process is slower due to the presence of the energy conservation law.

High energy states: For an ensemble of initial random direct product states |Î¨0âŸ©ketsubscriptÎ¨0|\Psi_{0}\rangle with Hamiltonian expectation value in the small energy interval Eâˆˆ[âˆ’0.1,0.1]ğ¸0.10.1E\in[-0.1,0.1] (i.e. E=âŸ¨Î¨0|H^|Î¨0âŸ©ğ¸quantum-operator-productsubscriptÎ¨0^ğ»subscriptÎ¨0E=\langle\Psi_{0}|{\hat{H}}|\Psi_{0}\rangle in the middle of the spectrum of the Ising Hamiltonian H^^ğ»{\hat{H}} in (14)), the EE grows linearly with time until tâ‰ˆ7ğ‘¡7t\approx 7 and then saturates exponentially to the final volume law at longer times around t=100ğ‘¡100t=100 [see inset in Fig.Â 7(b)]. Since this initial state has energy Eğ¸E close to zero (middle of the spectrum of H^^ğ»{\hat{H}}), the effective temperature is high and the saturation value of the EE is only slightly smaller than the Page value. In particular, when LA=9subscriptğ¿ğ´9L_{A}=9 (total system size L=20ğ¿20L=20), the difference between the two values of the EE is seen to be around 0.0045, which is less than 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the EE of the Page state.

In Fig.Â 7, we present results for the spectral form factors gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle and gcâ€‹(Ï„)=subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœabsentg_{c}(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©âˆ’âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)âŸ©â€‹âŸ¨Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle at different times tğ‘¡t. In Fig.Â 7, the â€œrampâ€ in gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau) starts to emerge at around t=9ğ‘¡9t=9. As tğ‘¡t increases further, the dip becomes deeper and shifts to earlier times. In Fig.Â 7 we plot the connected spectral form factor gcâ€‹(Ï„)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğœg_{c}(\tau), which is seen to exhibit a â€œrampâ€ that continues to grow further in length, even beyond time t=15ğ‘¡15t=15. This indicates that the energy conservation law makes the Ising model â€œless chaoticâ€ than the Floquet model, in the sense that universal spectral correlations do not extend to pairs of eigenvalues Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} as far separated as in the Floquet model. We have also computed the spectral form factor using only a subset of eigenvalues of Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) in a window around an eigenvalue at the top, in the middle and at the bottom of its spectrum and we find similar behavior as in the Floquet model: Universal spectral correlations first emerge at the top of the spectrum and then spread over the rest of spectrum.

Lower energy states: Since for the Ising model energy is conserved, we can also study the spectral correlations of Ï^Aâ€‹(t)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) which arise upon time evolution starting from an initial state with a lower energy Eğ¸E (= Hamiltonian expectation value =âŸ¨Ïˆ0|H^|Ïˆ0âŸ©absentquantum-operator-productsubscriptğœ“0^ğ»subscriptğœ“0=\langle\psi_{0}|{\hat{H}}|\psi_{0}\rangle) corresponding to properties of the quantum Ising Hamiltonian (14) at relatively low temperatures. (Though, Eğ¸E is separated from the ground state by many levels. The spectrum of H^^ğ»{\hat{H}} has support in an interval which is approximately [âˆ’26,+33]2633[-26,+33].) Furthermore, we introduce some randomness into this ensemble of initial states so that we can perform a disorder (ensemble) average over them. Under the unitary time evolution evolution, the EE is found to initially grow linearly with time tğ‘¡t, and to saturate as expected to a smaller volume law after long time evolution as compared to the case of a random initial state with energy Eğ¸E in the middle of the spectrum of H^^ğ»{\hat{H}}. For LA=9subscriptğ¿ğ´9L_{A}=9 (total system size L=20ğ¿20L=20), we start to observe a dip in the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle at times around t=9ğ‘¡9t=9. Finally, we turn off the longitudinal field hzsubscriptâ„ğ‘§h_{z} in the quantum Ising Hamiltonian (14), so that the model becomes integrable. An initial random direct product state equilibrates after the quantum quench to a thermal state described by the generalized Gibbs ensemble (GGE) with an extensive number of conserved quantities.RigolÂ etÂ al. (2007, 2006); CalabreseÂ andÂ Cardy (2007) As shown in Fig.Â 9, we do not observe any â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle, indicating the absence of chaos reflected in the absence of universal spectral correlations in the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}.

III.3 Floquet system with prethermal regime

As discussed before, for a generic Floquet system the reduced density matrix of a general short-range entangled initial state will reach a steady state at infinite temperature after a sufficiently long time evolution, since energy is not conserved.KimÂ etÂ al. (2014); Dâ€™AlessioÂ andÂ Rigol (2014); PonteÂ etÂ al. (2015); Dâ€™AlessioÂ andÂ Polkovnikov (2013) How thermal equilibrium and chaos emerge in the wavefunction is model-dependent. Recently, it has been shown that a rapidly driven system may exhibit an intermediate prethermal regime of long duration in which the system reaches a thermal equilibrium state governed by an approximate time-independent Hamiltonian with the effective temperature set by the initial energy.MoriÂ etÂ al. (2016); AbaninÂ etÂ al. (2015, 2017); ElseÂ etÂ al. (2017); MachadoÂ etÂ al. (2017) This regime can have an exponentially long lifetime (in units of inverse frequency, and other parameters of the system). We note that a prethermalized regime in a system with a time-independent (as opposed to Floquet) Hamiltonian has also been considered recently in the context of non-integrable perturbations of integrable many-body systems121212See e.g. Ref. BertiniÂ etÂ al., 2016 and references therein., but we do not discuss these situations here.

In this section, we are going to explore a Floquet model that exhibits such prethermalization to a thermal state which is close to that of a nearly-integrable system. The Floquet operator that we use to achieve such a prethermalized regime takes the following form,

U^F=expâ¡[âˆ’iâ€‹t0â€‹H^1]â€‹expâ¡[âˆ’iâ€‹t0â€‹H^2],subscript^ğ‘ˆğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡0subscript^ğ»1ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡0subscript^ğ»2\displaystyle\hat{U}_{F}=\exp[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{1}]\exp\left[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{2}\right]~{}, (16)

where

H^1=âˆ’âˆ‘j=1Lâˆ’1Ïƒ^jzâ€‹Ïƒ^j+1zâˆ’hxâ€‹âˆ‘j=1LÏƒ^jxsubscript^ğ»1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¿1superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘—ğ‘§superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘—1ğ‘§subscriptâ„ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¿superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘—ğ‘¥\displaystyle\hat{H}_{1}=-\sum_{j=1}^{L-1}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{z}\hat{\sigma}_{j+1}^{z}-h_{x}\sum_{j=1}^{L}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{x}
H^2=âˆ’hyâ€‹âˆ‘j=1LÏƒ^jy.subscript^ğ»2subscriptâ„ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¿superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘—ğ‘¦\displaystyle\hat{H}_{2}=-h_{y}\sum_{j=1}^{L}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{y}~{}. (17)

This model is a one-dimensional periodically driven system with period T=2â€‹t0ğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘¡0T=2t_{0}. In the numerical calculations, we choose open boundary conditions and system parameters (hx,hy)=(1,1)subscriptâ„ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘¦11(h_{x},h_{y})=(1,1). The period T=0.2ğ‘‡0.2T=0.2 is chosen to be very small in order to realize a long prethermal regime.

Since the period Tğ‘‡T is very small, it takes a large number of time-steps for the Floquet system to relax to its ultimate, fully thermalized (chaotic) state. The previous method used above for rapidly thermalizing Floquet systems that simply amounted to applying the time-evolution operator many times to an initial state, which did not require diagonalizing the Floquet operator, is no longer useful here due to the large number of required time-steps. Here we will instead consider a smaller system size with L=14ğ¿14L=14 so that we can diagonalize the Floquet operator explicitly and study the long time dynamics by applying that operator for any length of time to the initial state. We start with a random direct product state and evolve it under the Floquet operator. The result for the time evolution of the EE is shown in Fig.Â 10, where we clearly observe a long intermediate plateau which corresponds to the prethermalized regime. We further have computed the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)=ğ‘”ğœabsentg(\tau)= âŸ¨Zâ€‹(Ï„)â€‹Zâˆ—â€‹(Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘ğœsuperscriptğ‘ğœ\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle in this (prethermalized) regime and we do not observe any dip or â€œrampâ€, demonstrating that the eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix Ï^Aâ€‹(t=nâ€‹T)subscript^ğœŒğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘‡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT) do not exhibit any universal spectral correlations in this regime. The lack of the spectral correlations shows that chaos is absent in this regime, and we expect that it is described by a Generalized Gibbs Ensemble (GGE). On the other hand, chaos starts to appear at yet longer times where the EE increases further and eventually relaxes to the Page value; at those longer times, a small â€œrampâ€ is seen to develop in the spectral form factor depicted in Fig.Â 11 (b). A more pronounced linear â€œrampâ€ can be observed (see Fig. 11) once the state reaches full thermalization at still larger time-steps nğ‘›n.

Therefore, in the present Floquet model, we can separate the long time evolution into four stages (see Fig.sÂ 10 and 11): (1) a regime of linear growth of the EE, which also appears in all of the previous models (see inset of Fig.Â 10), (2) the prethermal regime described by GGE and absence of chaos, which is reflected by a plateau in the time-evolution of the EE, (3) the regime of development of chaos where universal spectral correlations start to develop at the top of the spectrum of the density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, and (4) the fully thermalized regime, where the initial state has time-evolved into a state whose reduced density matrix exhibits a spectrum indistinguishable from that of the density matrix of a featureless â€œrandom pure stateâ€.

IV Analytical calculations for the â€œrandom pure stateâ€

IV.1 Random pure state and Wishart-Laguerre ensemble

In this subsection we briefly review the connection between the reduced density matrix of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ (Page state) and the Wishart random matrix ensemble. First, we decompose the total Hilbert space into a tensor product of the Hilbert spaces of the two subsystems Ağ´A and BğµB with dimensions NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A} and NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B}, respectively (assuming NAâ‰¤NBsubscriptğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘ğµN_{A}\leq N_{B} without loss of generality), and write the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ defined in (5) in a direct (tensor) product basis

V Discussion and Conclusion

In conclusion, we have explored the presence of universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of a many-body wavefunction and used the presence of these correlations to define quantum chaos at the level of a single many-body wavefunction. To detect these spectral correlations, we constructed the spectral form factor gâ€‹(Ï„)ğ‘”ğœg(\tau) for Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} and identified the presence of a â€œrampâ€ as a hallmark of the spectral correlations. We explicitly considered three wavefunctions: the â€œrandom pure stateâ€, a typical state of a Floquet spin model, and of a quantum Ising model in both transverse and longitudinal fields, both in one spatial dimenstion. In all three cases, we numerically found the presence of the universal linear â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor. For the â€œrandom pure stateâ€, we also analytically computed the spectral form factor by using Wishart random matrix theory and found agreement with our numerical results.

Moreover, we discussed how universal spectral correlations develop in a quantum quench problem from an initial product state lacking chaos. We found that the spectral correlations first emerge at the top of spectrum of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, and then spread over the entire spectrum at later times. We verified this statement numerically in both, the Floquet and quantum Ising models. Finally we studied a rapidly driven Floquet system which posseses a long prethermalized regime exhibiting an â€œEE plateauâ€, on which the system can be well approximated by a GGE. For times when the system is on that EE plateau, we donâ€™t observe any â€œrampâ€ in the spectral form factor, which is consistent with the absence of chaos in the GGE. We found that universal spectral correlations (and a â€œrampâ€) in the density matrix develop only when the wavefunction starts to relax to the fully thermalized regime at late times.

Appendix A Spectral Form Factor of the Entanglement Hamiltonian

Numerical results for the spectral form factor of the entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^ğ»ğ¸{\hat{H}}_{E} of the â€œrandom pure stateâ€ are displayed in Fig. 12, and are to be compared with the spectral form factor of the reduced density matrix Ï^Asubscript^ğœŒğ´{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the same system, depicted in Fig. 2. We see that both spectral form factors exhibit a linear â€œrampâ€ (unit slope on a the log-log plot), which is the hallmark of universal spectral correlations. The form factors of the entanglement Hamiltonian are shifted by a NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A}-dependent constant on the log-log plot, which reflects a NAsubscriptğ‘ğ´N_{A}-dependent prefactor of the linear Ï„ğœ\tau-dependence.
